parsetree.*:
<root><template><title>Command</title><part><name>Comments</name>=<value>
____________________________________________________________________________________________

</value></part><part><name index="1"/><value> arma </value></part><part><name>Game name</name>=<value>

</value></part><part><name index="2"/><value>1.00</value></part><part><name>Game version</name>=<value>

</value></part><part><name>gr1</name>=<value> Positions </value></part><part><name>GROUP1</name>=<value>
____________________________________________________________________________________________

</value></part><part><name index="3"/><value> Converts map screen coordinates into world coordinates. Unlike [[ctrlMapScreenToWorld]], this command returns world position is format [x, y, 0], otherwise it is identical to [[ctrlMapScreenToWorld]].</value></part><part><name>DESCRIPTION</name>=<value>
____________________________________________________________________________________________

</value></part><part><name index="4"/><value> map '''posScreenToWorld''' [x, y] </value></part><part><name>SYNTAX</name>=<value>

</value></part><part><name>p1</name>=<value> map : [[Control]] - map control </value></part><part><name>PARAMETER1</name>=<value>

</value></part><part><name>p2</name>=<value> [x, y]: [[Array]] </value></part><part><name>PARAMETER2</name>=<value>
</value></part><part><name>p3</name>=<value> x: [[Number]] - screen X </value></part><part><name>PARAMETER3</name>=<value>
</value></part><part><name>p4</name>=<value> y: [[Number]] - screen Y</value></part><part><name>PARAMETER4</name>=<value>

</value></part><part><name index="5"/><value> [[Array]] - world position in format [x,y,0] </value></part><part><name>RETURNVALUE</name>=<value>
____________________________________________________________________________________________

</value></part><part><name>x1</name>=<value> <code>_worldCoord = _control [[posScreenToWorld]] _ScreenCoord;</code> </value></part><part><name>EXAMPLE1</name>=<value>
</value></part><part><name>x2</name>=<value> <code>_worldCoord = _control [[posScreenToWorld]] [_x, _y];</code> </value></part><part><name>EXAMPLE2</name>=<value>
</value></part><part><name>x3</name>=<value> <code>_worldCoord = _control [[posScreenToWorld]] [0.5, 0.5];</code> </value></part><part><name>EXAMPLE3</name>=<value>
_______________________________________________________________________

</value></part><part><name index="6"/><value> [[posWorldToScreen]], [[ctrlMapScreenToWorld]], [[ctrlMapWorldToScreen]] </value></part><part><name>SEEALSO</name>=<value>

</value></part></template>

<h3 style="display:none">Notes</h3>
<dl class="command_description">

<comment><!-- Note Section BEGIN -->
</comment><dd class="notedate">Posted on April 7, 2007 - 10:03
<dt class="note">[[User:LowFly|LowFly]]<dd class="note">''Notes:''

You can get the screen coordinates by the [[User_Interface_Event_Handlers|UI Event Handlers]] onMouseButtonDown, onMouseButtonUp, onMouseButtonClick, onMouseButtonDblClick.  

The return Array is in 2-D, you can use it with all set-position commands.
<ext><name>pre</name><attr/><inner>_x = returnArray select 0;
_y = returnArray select 1;</inner><close></pre></close></ext>


<comment><!-- Note Section END -->
</comment></dl>
